quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: Most productivity metrics are a lie. If the goal is more lines of code, I can prompt something to write the longest piece of code ever. It's just too easy to game that system and then introduce complexity and technical debt into all of the work that you're doing.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: DevEx is important because it enables all of that software creation, all of that problem solving. It enables the super rapid experimentation with customers. Before, you'd need a while for a prototype and maybe a little bit longer to actually flight it through an A/B test on a production system. You can do it in hours, right now.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: The best thing you can do is go talk to people and listen. Start with listening and not with tools and automation. So many times companies are like, 'I'm just going to build this tool.' Often you build a thing that you yourself have had a challenge with or that is easy to automate. If you just go talk to people, you can surface things that are relatively low lift and still have impact.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: Most teams can move faster. But faster for what? We can ship trash faster every single day. We need strategy and really smart decisions to know what to ship, what to experiment with, what features we want to do in what order and what rollout. The strategy is the core piece, and then think about speeding that up.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: If you're just looking at output, you can get there in a lot of different ways. But if you're getting there in ways that are high toil or high friction, then at some point, a developer is going to burn out. Or if it's super high cognitive load, you don't have the brain space left to come up with really innovative solutions.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: Now, we can also make a 45-minute work block useful because getting into the flow is actually kind of handed off, at least in part to the machine. Or the machine can help us get back into the flow by reminding us of context and generating diagrams of the system.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: We can't just blindly apply the existing metrics we've used before because we'll miss super important phenomenon and changes in the way people work. DORA metrics, SPACE - if it is a prescriptive metric, it needs to be used only in the way it was prescribed.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: LLMs are non-deterministic. We can't just put in a command and guess something back and accept it. We really need to evaluate it. Are we seeing hallucinations? What's the reliability? Does it meet the style that we would typically write?

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: Better documentation and the better comments you have, the better performance you're going to get out of your AI tools. Agents rely on good data because it's all about how they've been trained or how they've been grounded. And better data gives you better outcomes.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: Bring a product mindset to any type of DevEx improvements and the metrics we collect. We want to identify a problem, make sure we're solving a problem for a set of users. We want to think about creating MVPs and experiments and get fast feedback, do some rapid iteration. We want to have a strategy.

quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.text: I don't love a happiness survey because there are too many things that contribute to happiness. What can be helpful is satisfaction. You can ask, 'Are you satisfied with this tool?' Happy devs make happy code. They write better programs, they do better work. But capturing and trying to directly influence happiness is too all-encompassing.

takeaways: Most productivity metrics are a lie in the AI era - lines of code, PRs, and even DORA metrics can't be blindly applied anymore because AI has fundamentally changed feedback loops and how code gets written.
Speed without strategy is just shipping trash faster - the most important productivity gain isn't writing code faster, it's ensuring you're building and experimenting with the right things.

Start improving developer experience by listening, not building tools - go talk to developers about their day-to-day friction points, and you'll often find low-lift process changes that have outsized impact.

AI is reshaping flow states by making shorter work blocks productive - machines can help developers re-enter flow by providing context, generating diagrams, and handling the mechanical aspects of coding.

Treat developer experience as a product with a PM mindset - identify problems for specific users, build MVPs, get fast feedback, iterate rapidly, and know when to sunset metrics and tools that no longer serve their purpose.

contrarian_candidates.why: Boldly declares most productivity metrics are a lie - challenges the entire measurement-obsessed engineering culture
Teams can always move faster but shipping trash faster is pointless - pushes back against the velocity-at-all-costs mentality
